title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
code: library(ggplot2) library(ggcalheat)  set.seed(2026)  calendar_theme <- theme_minimal(base_size = 11) +   theme(     panel.grid = element_blank(),     axis.title = element_blank(),     axis.text = element_blank(),     axis.ticks = element_blank()   )

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: vignette uses multi-year daily series (2022 2025) show calendar heatmaps larger data.
code: all_dates <- seq.Date(as.Date("2022-01-01"), as.Date("2025-12-31"), by = "day") n <- length(all_dates)  doy <- as.integer(format(all_dates, "%j")) dow <- as.POSIXlt(all_dates)$wday is_weekend <- dow %in% c(0, 6)  traffic <- data.frame(   date = all_dates,   value = pmax(     0,     round(       24 +         9 * sin(2 * pi * doy / 365.25) +         ifelse(is_weekend, -8, 2) +         rnorm(n, sd = 4)     )   ) ) traffic$year <- format(traffic$date, "%Y")  nrow(traffic) #> [1] 1461

what: 1) Basic usage on large daily series
title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
code: ggplot(traffic, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   facet_wrap(~year, ncol = 1, scales = "free_x") +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#2C7FB8", name = "Traffic") +   labs(title = "Daily traffic (2022-2025)") +   calendar_theme

what: 2) Signed data with a diverging scale
title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: values include negative positive values, use diverging fill scale midpoint = 0.
code: anomaly <- data.frame(   date = seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-12-31"), by = "day") )  anomaly_doy <- as.integer(format(anomaly$date, "%j")) anomaly$value <- round(   2.5 * sin(2 * pi * anomaly_doy / 365.25) + rnorm(nrow(anomaly), sd = 1.8),   2 )  ggplot(anomaly, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   scale_fill_gradient2(     low = "#B2182B",     mid = "white",     high = "#2166AC",     midpoint = 0,     name = "Anomaly"   ) +   labs(title = "Signed daily anomalies") +   calendar_theme

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: default, geom_calendar() uses Sunday first day week. can switch Monday.
code: q1_2025 <- traffic[   traffic$date >= as.Date("2025-01-01") &     traffic$date <= as.Date("2025-03-31"), ]  ggplot(q1_2025, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar(week_start = "monday") +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#1B9E77", name = "Traffic") +   labs(title = "Q1 2025, Monday-first calendar") +   calendar_theme

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: geom_calendar() can fill missing dates larger display range using na_value.
code: sparse <- data.frame(   date = sort(sample(     seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-12-31"), by = "day"),     120   )),   value = rpois(120, lambda = 6) )  ggplot(sparse, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar(     start_date = as.Date("2024-11-01"),     end_date = as.Date("2025-12-31"),     na_value = 0   ) +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#D95F02", name = "Events") +   labs(title = "Sparse data completed over an explicit window") +   calendar_theme

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: source multiple rows per day, geom_calendar() aggregates day sum(value).
code: events <- data.frame(   date = sample(     seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-06-30"), by = "day"),     size = 2500,     replace = TRUE   ),   value = rgamma(2500, shape = 2.5, rate = 1 / 1.5) )  ggplot(events, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#7570B3", name = "Sum/day") +   labs(title = "Event-level rows aggregated per day") +   calendar_theme

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: can control tile geometry borders denser lighter visual style.
code: yr2024 <- traffic[traffic$year == "2024", ]  ggplot(yr2024, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar(     cell_width = 0.85,     cell_height = 0.85,     color = "white",     linewidth = 0.25   ) +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "#F7FCF5", high = "#238B45", name = "Traffic") +   labs(title = "2024 with tighter tiles and white borders") +   calendar_theme

title: ggcalheat: calendar heatmaps with ggplot2
text: Calendar heatmaps can faceted like regular ggplot2 layers.
code: teams <- c("North", "Central", "South") team_data <- do.call(   rbind,   lapply(seq_along(teams), function(i) {     d <- seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-12-31"), by = "day")     seasonal <- 20 + 7 * sin(2 * pi * as.integer(format(d, "%j")) / 365.25)     data.frame(       team = teams[i],       date = d,       value = pmax(0, round(seasonal + i * 3 + rnorm(length(d), sd = 3)))     )   }) )  ggplot(team_data, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   facet_wrap(~team, ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#66A61E", name = "Value") +   labs(title = "Team calendars") +   calendar_theme

title: Calendar heatmaps in R
text: Signed values supported directly standard continuous scales: See examples
code: library(ggplot2) library(ggcalheat)  set.seed(1) df <- data.frame(   date = seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-03-31"), by = "day"),   value = rpois(90, lambda = 3) )  ggplot(df, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   scale_fill_gradient(low = "grey95", high = "#2C7FB8") df_signed <- data.frame(   date = seq.Date(as.Date("2025-01-01"), as.Date("2025-02-28"), by = "day"),   value = rnorm(59, mean = 0, sd = 2) )  ggplot(df_signed, aes(date = date, value = value)) +   geom_calendar() +   scale_fill_gradient2(     low = "#B2182B",     mid = "white",     high = "#2166AC",     midpoint = 0   )

title: Calendar heatmap geometry — geom_calendar
text: geom_calendar() draws one tile per day computes calendar positions input data. Users need map date value; week/day placement handled internally.

title: Calendar heatmap geometry — geom_calendar
code: geom_calendar(   mapping = NULL,   data = NULL,   ...,   week_start = "sunday",   start_date = NULL,   end_date = NULL,   na_value = 0,   cell_width = 0.95,   cell_height = 0.95,   color = NA,   linewidth = 0,   na.rm = FALSE,   show.legend = NA,   inherit.aes = TRUE )

title: Calendar heatmap geometry — geom_calendar
text: mapping Set aesthetic mappings created ggplot2::aes(). Must include date value. data data frame. ... Additional parameters passed ggplot2::layer(). week_start First day week. One "sunday", "monday", 0, 1. start_date Optional lower date bound displayed range. end_date Optional upper date bound displayed range. na_value Value assigned dates missing input data. cell_width Width day tile. cell_height Height day tile. color Tile border color. linewidth Tile border line width. na.rm Passed ggplot2::geom_tile() control NA handling. show.legend layer included legends? inherit.aes FALSE, overrides global aesthetics.
